Minutas da Assembleia da República Portuguesa, Sessão 4, Número 82
Minutes of the Assembly of the Portuguese Republic, Session 4, Number 82

respStmt.resp: Machine translation to English and linguistic analysis of the translation
Annotating MTed corpora with USAS semantic tags

funder.orgName: Centre of Linguistics of the University of Lisbon

availability.p: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License

bibl.title: Minutes of the Assembleia da República of Portugal

projectDesc.p: ParlaMint is a project that aims to (1) create a multilingual set of comparable corpora of parliamentary proceedings uniformly encoded according to the ParlaMint encoding guidelines, covering the period from 2015 to mid-2022; (2) add linguistic annotations to the corpora and machine-translate them to English; (3) make the corpora available through concordancers; and (4) build use cases in Political Sciences and Digital Humanities based on the corpus data.

prefixDef.p: Private URIs with this prefix point to aligned source elements of the MTed corpus.

div.head: Sábado, 4 de maio de 2019 I Série — Número 82
XIII LEGISLATURA 4.ª SESSÃO LEGISLATIVA (2018-2019)
div.note: 2nd PLENARY SESSION OF 3 MAY 2019
Chairman: H.E. Mr. Eduardo Luís Barreto Ferro Rodrigues
Secretaries: Ex.mos Sr. Emilia de Fátima Moreira Santos Sandra Maria Pereira Pontedeira António Carlos Bivar Branco de Penha Monteiro Ana Sofia Ferreira Araújo

SUMMARY The President declared the meeting open at 10 a.m. and 3 minutes. The entry into the Bureau of the Proposal for a Law No 198/XIII/4a was given. The general debate was held on draft Law No 1204/XIII/4.a (BE) — Adoption of the guidelines of the National Railway Plan and an investment programme for its implementation, which was subsequently rejected. During the debate, Mr. Heitor de Sousa (BE) (a), Mr. Émídio Guerreiro (PSD), Mr. Bruno Dias (PCP), Mr. Hélder Amaral (CDS-PP), Mr. Carlos Pereira (PS), Mr. Maria Manuel Rola (BE), Mr. Fernando Virgílio Macedo (PSD), Mr. João Dias (PCP), Mr. José Luís Ferreira (Os Verdes), Mr. Carlos Silva (PSD), Mr. Fernando Manuel Barbosa (BE), Mr. Pedro Coimbra, Mr. Hugo Costa and Mr. Pedro Murcela (PS), Mr. Jorge Falcato Simões (BE), Mr. Helga Correia and Mr. Fátima Ramos (PSD), Mr. Hortense Martins (PS) and Mr. Pedro Filipe Soares (BE). Vote No 820/XIII/4a was read and approved (presented by the PSD and subscribed by PS Members) — Despite the death of Commander Angel Azevedo, after which the Chamber kept 1 minute silence. The following votes were adopted: No 821/XIII/4a (presented by the PS and subscribed by a PSD member) — From praise to the football team of the Sporting Club of Portugal for the conquest of the Futsal Champions League; No 822/XIII/4a (presented by the PS and subscribed by PS MPs) — From praise to the football team of the Football Club of Porto for the conquest of UEFA Youth League 2019; No 823/XIII/4a (presented by PSD and subscribed by PS) — From praise to the futsal team of the Sporting Club of Portugal; No 824/XIII/4a (presented by the PSD and subscribed by PS) — From praise to the sub-19 team of the Football Club of Porto. The proposal for a resolution No 87/XIII/4.a (GOV) was adopted by a general vote — Adoption of the Agreement on Air Transport between the Portuguese Republic and the Republic of Angola signed in Luanda on 18 September 2018. The proposal for a resolution No 89/XIII/4.a (GOV) was adopted by a general vote — Adoption of the Agreement between the Portuguese Republic and the Republic of Peru on the Reduction of Procura and Prevention and Combating the Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances, signed in Lisbon on 30 January 2012. Resolution No 703/XIII/2.a (CDS-PP) was rejected — Flexibility of daycare hours through social security cooperation agreements, incentives to be established by companies and promotion of agreements between childcare establishments and employers. Resolution No. 704/XIII/2.a (CDS-PP) was rejected — It recommends that the Government increase from three to five cycles of drug-assisted reproductive treatments shared by the National Health Service. Draft resolution No 715/XIII/2.a (PS) was approved — It recommends that the Government adopt measures to promote reconciliation between professional, family and personal life. In general, the following draft resolutions were adopted: No 2013/XIII/4a (PCP) — Recommends that the Government intensify control of invasive species in the Peneda-Gerês National Park; No 2076/XIII/4a (PSD) — Recommends that the Government undertake to draw up a national plan of forest control and eradication of invasive species in protected areas; No 2089/XIII/4a (PAN) — Recommends that the Government develop a national plan of action for the surveillance and control of woody alien invaders, giving priority to protected areas; No 2104/XIII/4a (Os Verdes) — Plan of action to monitor, monitor and eliminate woody invasive species, in particular in protected areas and in areas covered by fire; No 2107/XIII/4a (BE) — Recommends to the Government to intensify the fight against exotic species. With regard to the final text, submitted by the National Defence Commission, on the Proposal for a Law No 172/XIII/4a (GOV) — Approval of the Military Programming Act, the plenary took the indexary votes in the speciality, in the Commission, and then that final text was adopted in a comprehensive final vote, with the votes of the absolute majority of Members in effective office. The final text, submitted by the Health Committee, on draft Law No. 1007/XIII/4a (BE) — Access to civil identity of gameta donors by persons born as a result of treatment or procedures for the production of assisted medicinal products and the creation of a transitional standard for donations prior to 24 April 2018 (fifth amendment to Law No. 32/2006 of 26 July), 1010/XIII/4a (PSD) — Conditions for access to information on the civil identification of donors in the context of assisted medicinal products, 1024/XIII/4a (PS) — Fifth amendment to Law No. 32/2006, 26 July (Procurement of Medicinal Products Assisted) — Conditions for confidentiality of donors under the provisions of Decree No. 225/2018, of 24 April 2018, of the Constitutional Court, 1031/XIII/4.a (PCP) and of July 26 July (Acts of Procedures No. 26 Assisted Drug Law, of Regulation No. Speakers Carla Cruz (PCP), Moisés Ferreira (BE), Isabel Alves Moreira (PS) and Ángela Guerra (PSD) voted. The proposal for Law No 39/XIII/2.a (ALRAM) was generally rejected — the tenth amendment to the Labour Code and the fourth amendment to Decree-Law No 91/2009 of 9 April 2009 in its current wording, with a view to strengthening the protection regime in parenthood. The replacement text, submitted by the Committee on Labour and Social Security, concerning draft Law No. 177/XIII/1.a (PCP) — Strengthening of the rights of maternity and paternity rights, 354/XIII/2.a (PCP) — Strengthening the protection of pregnant workers, women and infants and workers in the enjoyment of parental leave and the amendment of the Labour Code and of the Labour and Labour Labour Act in Public functions, 462/XIII/2.a (PCP) — Strengthening the protection of maternity and parental rights of maternity and maternity rights rights, 354/XIII/2.a (PCP) — Strengthening the protection of pregnant workers, women and infants and infants and workers and workers in the enjoyment of parental leave in the parental leave of parental leave and of paternity and paternal rights of paternity and paternity and paternity and paternity and parentee status (PCP) — Strengthening up to pre-born or during the age of the period of birth of the child, 214/Act of working status,???????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????????? Following the approval of two requests submitted by the CDS-PP and the PCP for a vote by the plenary on the speciality of the proposed amendments, submitted by the CDS-PP and the PCP, draft Law Nos 431/XIII/2.a and 455/XIII/2.a (CDS-PP) and draft Law No 177/XIII/1.a (PCP), Mr Rita Rato (PCP), Mr Carla Tavares (PS), Mr Clara Marques Mendes (PSD), Mr José Moura Soeiro (BE) and Mr Filipe Anacoreta Correia (CDS-PP), and Mr Filipe Anacoreta Correia (CDS-PP) respectively, the proposals for amendments were rejected, and the plenary took the indexary votes held, especially at the Commission. That replacement text was then adopted in the overall final vote. The session was closed by 12 hours and 46 minutes. (a) during this intervention, images were projected.
Images designed by BE Heitor de Sousa Member during the opening of the debate on draft Law No 1204/XIII/4.a (BE):

Explanations of vote sent to the Bureau for publication
Concerning the final text, submitted by the National Defence Commission, on the Proposal for a Law No 172/XIII/4.a:

The CDS voted in favour of the Government's Proposal for Law No 172/XIII/4a, which approves the Military Programming Law (MPL) because it considers the existence of this budgetary mechanism vital for the re-equipment of our Armed Forces.

We do not agree with the whole proposal because we consider that important capacities for the various branches have been insufficiently budgeted and because some important programmes have been out of the law.
The largest example is the lack of investment consistent with the Army's average capacity.
However, in a constructive spirit, we put forward proposals to improve the law, and some of these proposals have fostered agreements within the Commission with the PSD and PS.
However, we are alarming that the enforcement of the current law does not comply with the government's proclamation of non-captiveness.
In the LPM reports sent to Parliament, the Ministry of Defence, in this Parliament, has never met more than 90% and has reached 2018 as a lower performance than 2017.

The same reports warn that the use by the Ministry of Finance of the mechanism for the retention of funds available is detrimental to the effective implementation of the programmes. This mechanism is, for all purposes, capacitated capacitations.
The credibility of this new law will only be a reality when these files are completed.
The Member of the CDS-PP Parliamentary Group, João Rebelo.

Note: The statement of vote announced by PCP Member Jorge Machado concerning this plenary meeting was not delivered within the time limit provided for in Article 87(3) of the Rules of Procedure of the Assembly of the Republic.
For draft Law No 944/XIII/3.a (Citizens) (voted at the plenary meeting of 17 April 2019 — DAR I Series No 77 (2019-04-18):

The CFP reaffirms its position of defending the full time of service provided by public administration workers, including teachers, for the purposes of defrosting career progression, noting the failure by the Government of the State Budget Act (OE) for 2018 and the OE Law for 2019 to comply with its obligations in this regard.

The Law of the EPO 2018 established that all time of service must be considered, only to discuss between the government and the trade unions the way and the time within which payment of their remuneration is made. Instead of presenting and discussing with the unions the proposals for defining the way and the payment period of the remuneration valuation, the Socialist Party's Government closed its initial position of eradicating more than six and a half years of service.

Following the non-compliance with the 2018 plan, the 2019 EO Law finally recovered what was decided in the 2018 EO Law. The proposal of the CFP within the EO would have enabled the process to achieve the full response, which is now required for the Assembly of the Republic to take on the basis of the negotiating boycott led by the PS Government.

No one can today deny the need for the Assembly of the Republic to take a final decision on this problem, given that there are already recovery processes in force in Madeira and in the Azores resulting from negotiations with the trade unions and that they can be adopted and adapted to the continent.

Since the beginning of this whole process, the CFP has refused any initiatives that could give the Government an excuse not to assume its responsibilities or that contribute to harm the rights and interests of teachers, serving the objectives and the government's discourse voluntarily or unintentionally.

In view of these issues, the CFP abstained from draft Law No 944/XIII/3.a. By valuing the component of participation achieved, the truth is that this project, originating in the Citizens' Legislative Initiative (LCI), carries several risks and contradictions that the PCP identified in its own time. Moreover, on the basis of the publication, on the initiative of the Government, of Decree-Law No 36/2019 of 15 March, the situation has changed which must be taken into account.

As a result of these amendments, it has entered into the Assembly of the Republic a petition with more than 60 000 signatures, exclusively from teachers and educators, which points to the concrete options to be developed and which clearly reflects the meaning that best allows a solution to the scenario.

Thus, at the present stage of the process of counting the time of service, the Assembly of the Republic has the proposal of the CFP to resolve the situation created by responsibility of the Government of the Socialist Party. The following proposals and objectives were presented at the request of Parliamentary Review by the Portuguese Communist Party:
1. Ensuring full accounting of service time. It is 9 years, 4 months and 2 days that have to count for career progression because it was time worked.
2. To adopt the same negotiated solution, in terms of phase-out, between the trade unions and the Regional Government of Madeira, which corresponds to 7 years.
3. Ensure in 2019 the recovery of the time provided for in Decree-Law of the Government.
4. Eliminate the existence of surpluses resulting from the rules laid down in the Decree-Law of the Government.
5. Make it possible to use the time of service for the purpose of retirement or dispensation of obtaining a vacancy by the teacher's option.
6. Ensure that the work rendered as a hired teacher is relevant for the purposes of progression, ensuring non-discrimination depending on the nature of the bond.

The CFP considers that the proposals submitted correspond to the expectations of teachers and their fair claims. What the CFP wants is that they can be approved by the widest possible majority, in a process of rapid specialty. The CFP maintains its commitment to the interests and rights of workers, with the certainty that the development of the struggle will be a decisive factor for their realization.
Assembly of the Republic, 30 April 2019.
Members of the CFP Parliamentary Group, Ana Mesquita — Paula Santos.
Received in the Editorial Division on 30 April 2019
For Vote No 819/XIII/4.a (PSD, PS, CDS-PP, PAN and Nsc.) [voted at the plenary meeting of 26 April 2019 — DAR I Series No 80 (2019-04-27)]:

Although they have always fought for respect for life and for human rights, now as in any historical period, whether they are more or less distant, the signatories of this declaration have opted for abstention in the weighing vote referred to in the heading, although they recognize that they are imbued with a clear humanist spirit.

We do not intend to enter into the historical discussion on the veracity of the events in Turkey at the beginning of the last century, whether or not they can be qualified as a genocide or to whom responsibilities should be imposed. Much less they want subscribers to whiten any crimes against humanity, they have been perpetrated by which people or at what time.

We consider it important, however, to highlight the complexity and historical controversy surrounding the events known as the “Armenian Massacre attributed to the Ottoman Government”, since few (or no) peoples can claim in their history not to have any event of disrespect for the rights and dignity of the human person, which should not regret, especially if the look is taken to events that have occurred over the past one or more centuries.

At a time when people are asked to value what approaches them rather than what separates them, at a time when they become increasingly aware of the fact that only with union can many of the problems that affect mankind globally, known as the special sensitivity of the Turkish people to this period of their history and being the Republic of Turkey a precious ally of Portugal and of many European Union states in NATO, subscribers consider it important that no initiatives that contribute to deepen civilizational and/or religious fossils, which, unfortunately, have motivated many of the extremisms we have seen on a global scale, largely resulting from irrational hatreds and religious differences, anachronic and intolerable.
As Turkey is a partner and an ally, we assume the position that we consider appropriate to respect that we believe we deserve the feeling of its people, that we still want to have as friends.
Assembly of the Republic, 2 May 2019.
Members of the PSD Parliamentary Group, Pedro Roque — Nilza de Sena — Álvaro Batista.
Received in the Editorial Division on 3 May 2019
Concerning the final text of draft Law No 873 (PS) and 913/XIII/3.a (PSD) and 1012 (PAN) and 1018/XIII/4.a (CDS-PP) (voted at the plenary meeting of 26 April 2019 — DAR I Series No 80 (2019-04-27)):

Where there is a need to implement a protective promotion measure under placement arrangements, family care should be the measure to be preferred, to the detriment of residential care, particularly for children up to the age of six. It is the law that refers to it, as well as all scientific recommendations. All children have the right to grow in a family, and this is the context that should be privileged for the growth of a child, even for those who, for reasons of protection promotion, have become deprived of their natural context of life.

However, there are several challenges to the Portuguese reception system, including family care. In Portugal, of children with a measure of promotion and protection under placement, only about 3% are in family care. It is therefore clear that the Portuguese reception system has followed an opposite path to the other European countries, as far as this is concerned.

It was with the aim of boosting an action paradigm change that the PSD presented a set of proposals that aimed to increase the number of applicants to host families, through some incentives that reduced the costs and charges of host families. We are aware that the proposals submitted do not meet all of the needs expressed. However, we know that they provide a true catalytic axis for a change in the paradigm of action, thus contributing to a greater and better bet on family care as a measure of placing children and young people in danger. It should also be noted that many of the difficulties stem from the lack of regulation of the measure, which has only been published for public discussion today, almost four years after the entry into force of the new law on the protection of children and young people in danger.

The PSD Parliamentary Group must not fail to express its disappointment that it has not been possible to reach further, in particular through the adoption of the following proposals: (i) To ensure that the support granted to a host family is granted as a family allowance and not as a payment of a service benefit; (ii) To ensure that the child in a host family is entitled to the first step of the family allowance, which adds the disability bonus, as is the case with the payment of the family allowance of that same child to a foster institution.

We believe that this is the beginning of a new path and, despite not all the measures we consider necessary for this momentum, with the approval of this diploma, we are taking an assertive step towards the path of change. For this reason, we voted in favour of the amendment of Decree-Law No 11/2008 of 17 January in the overall final vote on the system for the implementation of family reception.
Saint Benedict Palace, April 26, 2019.
Members of the PSD Parliamentary Group.
Received in the Editorial Division on 3 May 2019
Concerning the final text of the Proposal for a Law No 150/XIII/4.a (GOV) (voted at the plenary meeting of 26 April 2019 — DAR I Series No 80 (2019-04-27):

The CFP Parliamentary Group opted for abstention in the final vote on the above-mentioned bill because, despite all the improvements made in the field of discussion in the specialty, in particular: the establishment of a genuine solidarity responsibility that benefits workers; the recovery of the value from which the transport of values is mandatory and the creation of supervisory mechanisms that provide for the articulation of various state bodies, we believe that problems still remain in the final version of the diploma.

Although the CFP submitted proposals for amendments which would refer to the collective employment contract the definition of professional categories and functional content thereof, this proposal would eventually not be approved. Thus, the law is implicated in a matter which is solely responsible for collective employment. Moreover, the definition of professional categories and functional content of these categories, different from those existing in collective employment, may cause labour problems that were duly signalled by the CFP Parliamentary Group, during the discussion on the speciality.
For these reasons, the position of the CFP is abstention in the overall final vote of this diploma.
Assembly of the Republic, 3 May 2019.
The Member of the CFP Parliamentary Group, Jorge Machado.
Received in the Editorial Division on 3 May 2019
Members' presences and shortcomings at the plenary meeting.
THE REDATION DIVISION.
